sect1.title: What is PLATOTerm 64?
sect1.para: PLATOTerm64 is a Terminal Emulator for your Commodore 64 computer that emulates a PLATO terminal. With PLATOTerm64, you can successfully access such internet-accessible services, such as IRATA.ONLINE, or CYBER1.ORG, which are unique services that you can access not only from your Commodore 64, but from many other vintage computers, as well.

PLATOTerm64 works on any Commodore 64 computer, or Commodore 128 computer running in Commodore 64 mode, and takes advantage of the Commodore 64's 320x200 graphics mode to provide the graphical display needed by a PLATO system. All of the keys present on a PLATO terminal are mapped to equivalent keys on the Commodore keyboard, and the PLATO terminal display is resized from its original 512x512 size, to fit on the 320x200 display provided by your Commodore 64. The touch display nominally provided by the PLATO terminal is simulated using either a supported mouse, light pen, or touch tablet.
System requirements, including peripheral requirements are addressed, below.

sect1.title: What is PLATO?
sect1.para: PLATO, which stood for Programmed Logic for Automatic Teaching Operations, was perhaps the first generalized computer assisted instruction system. The project, started in 1960, initially ran on the ILLIAC I computer at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and by the 1970s was supporting several thousand graphical terminals, distributed worldwide, running on nearly a dozen networked mainframe computers. Many innovations were originally developed on PLATO, and the purpose of PLATOTerm, and by extension, PLATO sites like IRATA.ONLINE, and CYBER1.ORG, exist to not only preserve the legacy of PLATO, but to expose its uniqueness to vintage computer users, and give them a unique online destination.

PLATO environments provide an interactive; graphical environment, that is controlled by both a keyboard and a touch screen, originally to facilitate what was thought to be required for Computer Based training, but was ultimately expanded into many other very unique innovations, due to the combination of unique technology and culture that grew up around the PLATO environment.

sect2.title: Knowing more about PLATO History and Culture
sect2.para: If you would like to know more about PLATO, as well as its origins and historical impact. You should read Brian Dear's book: The Friendly Orange Glow: The Untold Story of the PLATO System and the Dawn of Cyberculture.

sect1.title: Scope of this manual
sect1.para: This book is intended as an introductory user's guide to both PLATOTerm64, as well as an overview of the two extant PLATO services, IRATA.ONLINE and CYBER1.ORG. You will be shown the process of loading and configuring PLATOTerm64, as well as ensuring that you can connect to the two aforementioned services. It is important that you follow the instructions in this manual, to get the best experience you can out of these two services.

sect2.title: Corrections?
sect2.para: If you have any potential corrections, or otherwise improvements, you can either contact the author, or fork the documentation, make the changes, and issue a pull request on Github, as the documentation is open-source, and in an easy to understand XML format (DocBook 5.1, as of the time of this writing.) Once the pull request has been reviewed and approved, your name will be added to the credits of this manual.

chapter.title: Setting up PLATOTerm64
chapter.para: PLATOTerm64 is easy to set up. Once you have finished this chapter, PLATOTerm should be running and waiting to be able to connect to a PLATO service.

sect1.title: Hardware Requirements
sect1.para:
PLATOTerm64 requires the following hardware to function correctly:
Computer: A Commodore 64 or 128 running in Commodore 64 mode. SuperCPU is also supported.
Display: While a television can work. For best result, use a monitor connected via the monitor port. For modern displays, look at using a Commodore cable, connected to an S-Video to HDMI converter.
Disk Drive: PLATOTerm is distributed in D64 disk image format and must be transferred either to a device that can directly read D64 files, such as a SD2IEC, or it must be written to a floppy disk to be used in a Commodore 1541 or compatible disk drive. A Fast-Load cartridge, or ROM replacement like JiffyDOS is recommended for a fast loading experience.
Internet connectivity hardware: Since the current PLATO systems are connected to the Internet, your Commodore computer will need a wifi modem or Ethernet cartridge connected to an Internet accessible network. As of version 1.0, PLATOTerm64 supports the following devices:
An ESP8266 or similar WIFI/Ethernet modem connected to the user port, such as the ZiModem or commodore4ever WIFI modem. This uses the up2400 driver, and will connect at 2400bps.
A TCP or WIFI Modem connected via a Swiftlink-232, or compatible cartridge. This allows a transmission speed of up to 38400bps.
An ethernet cartridge supported by IP65, such as RRNet, or 64NIC+.
The up2400 and swiftlink drivers can also connect to a device running a serial bridge program such as tcpser, or a Lantronix UDS device.

sect1.title: Loading PLATOTerm64
sect1.para: PLATOTerm64 is loaded like most Commodore software. The first file on the disk is the PLATOTERM software, and if you load the * file, you will load the PLATOTerm program.

To load the PLATOTerm software, insert the disk into your drive. If you're using an SD2IEC or similar, you can either any built in loaders to select the disk image, or you can choose to enter the commands to mount the disk from BASIC.
Once you've mounted the disk, you can load the software with the following command:LOAD"*",8,1
And then the PLATOTerm64 splash screen will become visible, and wait for you to enter your first command.

sect1.title: PLATOTerm64 Disk Contents
sect1.para: The PLATOTerm64 disk directory can be accessed in the expected way, by typing the following command:LOAD"$",8
After the load, the contents can be displayed, with the following command:LIST
Which will display the directory of the disk.

The PLATOTerm64 disk contains the following files:
PLATOTERM - This is the main program, and since it is the first entry in the directory, is what's loaded when you load via a wildcard filename, as specified in the above instructions.
GPL-3.0 - This is a runnable program which displays the GPL-3.0 license, which is the license under which the program is distributed. It utilizes a soft 80 column display, in order to display the license cleanly on screen, so it is recommended that you have an appropriate monitor. It will probably not display properly on television displays connected via an RF modulator.
MOU-1351 - This is the touch screen driver for the Commodore 1351 mouse and compatible devices.The mouse is expected to be connected to joystick port 0 (the port closest to the front of the machine.) The MOU drivers are CC65 loadable modules utilizing its mouse API.
MOU-INKWELL - This is a touchscreen driver for an Inkwell light pen. The light pen is expected to be connected to port 1 (the port closest to the back of the machine), and as with all light pens, you should only use this device with a cathode ray tube (CRT) monitor such as a Commodore 1702 or similar. LCD monitors will not work properly with an Inkwell device.
MOU-JOY - This is a touchscreen driver for joysticks and mice that behave like joysticks (such as a Commodore 1350 mouse, or a standard 9-pin joystick or trackball.) It is expected that the joystick device be plugged into port 1 (the port closest to the back of the machine.)
MOU-POT - This is a touchscreen driver for potentiometer based devices, such as paddles or a Koala Pad connected to port 1 (the port closest to the back)
SER-SWLINK - This is the serial driver for a Swiftlink-232 cartridge, or one of its clones. These cartridges use a 6551 ACIA chip to provide RS-232 functions, and as such can transmit and receive baud rates up to 38,400.
SER-UP2400 - This is the serial driver for user port RS-232 devices. It is currently locked at a maximum rate of 2400 bits per second.
CONFIG - The CONFIG file is a sequential file storing the PLATOTerm64 preferences. It is created upon the first boot-up of PLATOTerm64, and is written to every time preferences are explicitly saved. It is loaded each time the program starts.

chapter.title: Setting up
chapter.para: Once PLATOTerm64 has been loaded for the first time, it must be conifgured to match your particular hardware setup.

sect1.title: Default Settings
sect1.para:
As shipped on the disk image, PLATOTerm has the following default settings:
Interface: Serial (also known as RS-232)
Driver: UP2400 (User Port running at 2400 bits per second)
Baud Rate: 2400 bits per second
Touch Interface: Commodore 1351 Mouse
Colors: Light blue on dark blue, with light blue border, like the Commodore 64 BASIC colors.

sect1.title: Setting Colors
sect1.para: PLATOTerm64 allows you to set desired colors for foreground and background utilizing any of the 16 available colors in the Commodore palette. For reference, a visual representation of the color palette is provided, below: (This chart comes from the MONTEST program, and is representative of output from an NTSC machine, PAL machines have slightly different colors): Commodore Color Palette

Pressing any of the following keys, will change the background, text, or border colors to the next position on the above color palette. Once the light grey color has been reached, the subsequent press of the key will select the black color from the palette.
To select the backgrouind color, press the F1 key.
To select the text color, press the F2 key by holding down SHIFT and the F1 key.
To select the border color, hold down the COMMODORE key, and press the F1 key.
Colors can also be selected using these keys, while in the Preferences menu.
Once the desired color palette has been selected, it can be saved using the S)AVE option in the preferences menu, as described below.

sect1.title: Setting Preferences
sect1.para: If for some reason, the default preferences aren't correct, such as needing to use a SWLink232 cartridge, or an IP65 supported Ethernet cartridge such as a 64NIC+, then you need to access the preferences menu, to change your settings to match your hardware configuration.

To access the preferences menu, press the F3 key. The preferences menu appears at the bottom of the PLATOTerm screen. Since the default setting specifies a serial interface, the preferences menu looks like:I)NTERFACE D)RIVER B)AUD T)OUCH S)AVE E)XIT:

To select an option, press its letter, indicated to the left of each paren, such as D to select the serial driver. The following subsections give a quick description of each option and its affect on configuring the program:

sect2.title: I)NTERFACE
sect2.para: I)NTERFACE presents a sub-menu to allow you to select either a serial or ethernet based interface. Each selection changes the main menu that displays when the F3 key is pressed.INTERFACE - E)THERNET S)ERIAL B)ACK:
If E)THERNET is selected, then the main menu will change to:I)NTERFACE D)HCP P)IP N)ETMASK G)ATEWAY W)DNS S)AVE E)XIT:

sect2.title: Serial Interface Preferences
sect2.para: The following items are available from the main menu, if S)ERIAL interface is selected:

sect3.title: D)RIVER
sect3.para:
D)RIVER presents a sub-menu to allow you to specify the driver to use for serial (RS-232) communication. This is needed because Commodore machines have multiple options for connecting RS-232 serial devices, each with their own advantages and disadvantages.DRIVER - S)WIFTLINK232 U)SERPORT2400 B)ACK:
If you have a Swiftlink-232 RS-232 cartridge that you wish to use, press S
If you have a user port based device you wish to use at 2400bps, press U

sect3.title: B)AUD
sect3.para: RS-232 devices connected via the Swiftlink-232 cartridge or user port require that the correct baud rate for your device is set. The most common baud rates are displayed to be selected. BAUD - 3)00 1)200 2)400 9)600 Q)19200 W)38400 B)ACK:
If there is a baud rate that isn't available here, feel free to contact the author, or submit a patch for your desired baud rate to GitHub.

While the Swiftlink can use any baud rate selectable, the UP2400 driver is currently locked at 2400 bits per second, and the B)AUD setting has no effect. (this may change to allow baud rates from 300 to 2400 bps.)

sect2.title: Ethernet Interface Preferences
sect2.para: The following items are available from the main menu, if E)THERNET interface is selected:

sect3.title: D)HCP
sect3.para:
This determines whether to use the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP), a protocol commonly used to configure TCP/IP devices on a network. If selected, and a DHCP host is found, PLATOTerm will enquire for an IP address, a netmask, a gateway, and a DNS server, and thus automatically set the manual parameters specified throughout the rest of the Ethernet Interface Preferences section.DHCP - Y)ES N)O
If you can utilize DHCP (most networks), press Y to automatically enquire for network settings.
If you need to set network settings manually, also known as static configuration, press N

important.para: If DHCP is selected, any information entered into the manual (static) configuration options below are also saved, but ignored while DHCP is set to Y

sect3.title: P)IP
sect3.para: This menu option is used to set the desired IP address that PLATOTerm will use to identify itself to the network. This information is dependent on your network configuration, so first determine if you need this option. If you do need this option, be sure that the IP address you choose is both a valid address for your network, and that it is available.
Once selected, PLATOTerm64 will ask you to input the desired IP address:IP ADDRESS (X.X.X.X) OR RETURN FOR NONE:
Valid characters are numbers and the period '.' character, such as: 192.168.1.2, This is an address belonging to a private class C network.
If you do not wish to enter a value here, or to erase the previous value, press RETURN.
Once your IP address has been entered, press the RETURN key to accept the selection. PLATOTerm64 will respond with the message: OK

sect3.title: N)ETMASK
sect3.para: The N)ETMASK menu option is used to specify the required N)ETMASK for the IP address that is configured using the P)IP menu option. This value is used by the underlying TCP/IP stack (IP65) to determine which addresses belong to the local network, versus which addresses need to be routed out the gateway address, which is specified using the G)ATEWAY option.
Once selected, PLATOTerm64 will ask you to input the desired netmask:NETMASK (X.X.X.X) OR RETURN FOR NONE:
Valid characters are numbers and the period '.' character, such as: 255.255.255.0, which specifies a netmask belonging to a class C network.
If you do not wish to enter a value here, or to erase the previous value, press RETURN.
Once your netmask has been entered, press the RETURN key to accept the selection, PLATOTerm64 will respond with the message:OK

sect3.title: G)ATEWAY
sect3.para: The G)ATEWAY menu option is use to specify the required G)ATEWAY to send traffic that is not destined for the local network. If the PLATO service you are connecting to is not on your local network, this option will need to be set to the IP address of your nearest router.
As with the N)ETMASK and P)IP address options, ensure that the values entered here are valid. If you are not sure, check other computers on your network for this value.
Once selected, PLATOTerm64 will ask you to input the desired gateway:GATEWAY (X.X.X.X) OR RETURN FOR NONE:

Valid characters are numbers and the period '.' character, such as: 192.168.1.1, this is an address belonging to a private class C network, and is a very common valuie for a gateway address, such as a home internet router.
If you do not wish to enter a value here, or to erase the previous value, press RETURN.
Once your gatway address has been entered, press the RETURN key to accept the selection. PLATOTerm64 will respond with the message:OK

sect3.title: W)DNS
sect3.para: The W)DNS menu option is use to specify the required domain name server to resolve host names to their respective IP addresses, while connecting to your desired PLATO host. This information is usually the same for all hosts on a network, and can be acquired by looking at the network information from other devices on the network, if needed.
As with the G)ATEWAY, N)ETMASK, and P)IP address options, ensure that the values entered here are valid. If you are not sure, check other computers on your network for this value.
Once selected, PLATOTerm64 will ask you to input the desired DNS server:DNS (X.X.X.X) OR RETURN FOR NONE:

Valid characters are numbers and the period '.' character, such as: 192.168.1.1, this is an address belonging to a private class C network, and is a very common valuie for a DNS address that is also the gatway, such as a home internet router.
If you do not wish to enter a value here, or to erase the previous value, press RETURN.
Once your DNS address has been entered, press the RETURN key to accept the selection. PLATOTerm64 will respond with the message:OK

sect2.title: T)OUCH
sect2.para: The Touch sub-menu shows a list of supported devices that the Commodore can use to simulate PLATO's touchscreen.TOUCH - 1)351 I)NKWELL J)OY K)OALA B)ACK:

listitem.para: If you have a Commodore 1351 mouse, press 1
If you have an Inkwell light pen, press I
If you have a Joystick, or Commodore 1350 "rolling joystick" mouse, press J
If you have a Koala pad, or other potentiometer device, such as paddles, press K

sect2.para: With the exception of the 1351 mouse, most of these devices should be connected to port 1, which is the controller port closest to the back of your Commodore computer.

sect2.title: S)AVE
sect2.para: Pressing S will save the currently selected preferences, including the currently selected color palette, to the CONFIG file on the disk.

sect2.title: E)XIT
sect2.para:
Pressing E will apply and use the currently selected preferences.
E)XIT will close all currently loaded drivers, regardless of whether they were reset or not. It is a good idea to set preferences BEFORE attempting to connect to your desired PLATO service, as any serial or ethernet connections currently opened will be closed as a result of reinitializing the various drivers.

note.para: Although there is not an explicit menu option to set colors in preferences, they can be selected in the preferences menu using the F1, F2 and COMMODORE-F1 keys, and they will be saved with the S)AVE command.

sect1.title: Configuring Your Connectivity Device
sect1.para: The following subsections describe configuration tips for various devices, and how best to configure them. If you have a suggested configuration that you think should go into this documetation, either contact the author with a full description of the suggested configuration, or check out a copy of this documentation from GitHuh, and add it.

sect2.title: About Serial (RS-232) Devices
sect2.para: This class of devices connect via an RS-232 interface, and typically act like a Hayes™ compatible MODEM, using AT commands to specify not only operating parameters, but to connect to the desired host, as well as to terminate the connection.

It does this by taking care of all the TCP/IP duties itself, and providing the resulting extracted data from each TCP/IP packet, over the serial connection. Thus, these serial devices are very beneficial if you wish to use existing terminal programs to connect to hosts on the Internet, without requiring special terminal software. They are also very inexpensive and easy to obtain.

Some examples of Serial devices:
ESP8266 devices, these can connect either directly to the user port, or via a high speed RS-232 interface such as the Swiftlink-232. These devices utilize a microcontroller to provide the TCP/IP stack.
commodore4ever ESP8266 WIFI Modem
Jim Drew's WiModem, also ESP8266 based.
Jamming Signal's Commodore WIFI Modem
An actual analog modem, connecting over telephone to a TCP/IP gateway service. (TODO: Ask Michael Lee to help add some information here!)

sect2.title: About Ethernet (TCP/IP) Devices
sect2.para:
While Serial devices behave like a Hayes™ compatible MODEM, TCP/IP operation in PLATOTerm works with the IP65 library (courtesy of Oliver Schmidt), to interface to a number of ethernet cartridges for the Commodore computer, such as:
RETRO Innovations' 64NIC+
RR-NET
Unlike the serial interfaces, PLATOTerm64 will provide a mechanism to select the desired PLATO host.

sect2.title: Configuring the commodore4ever WIFI MODEM v2.1
sect2.para: The commodore4ever WIFI MODEM, by default is configured to respond at 300 baud. Thus, PLATOTerm must have its data rate, initially set to this speed, in order to do its initial configuration.

With each step of the procedure, either PLATOTerm will report OK, if the preference setting was successful, or the MODEM will report OK, when the MODEM command is successful. If you see ERROR, please try re-typing the command, and possibly checking your network configuration to ensure it is working correctly.

The following procedure will configure your MODEM to work with PLATOTerm64, as well as other terminal programs that can properly support user port modems: How to configure the commodore4ever WIFI Modem 2.1
Access the Preferences menu.
Press F3 to access the Preferences menu.
Access the D)RIVER submenu.
Press D to select the D)RIVER submenu.
Select the UP2400 driver.
Press U to specify the UP2400 driver.
Select the Baud submenu.
Press B to select the B)AUD submenu.
Select 300 baud.
Press 3 to select 300 baud.
Exit preferences.
Press E to exit preferences, and return to the terminal.
Wake up the MODEM.
Once back in the terminal, press RETURN to wake up the modem. You will see the greeting from the MODEM.
Set the WIFI SSID.
Type the following, AT$SSID=<your_wifi_ssid> and press RETURN, replacing <your_ssid> with the SSID of your access point.
Optional: Set the WIFI Password.
If your WIFI network requires a password, type AT$PASS=<your_wifi_password>, and press RETURN replacing <your_wifi_password> with the password of your access point.
Connect to your WIFI network.
Once these parameters have been set, test the connection to the WIFI network by typing ATC1 and pressing RETURN The modem will indicate that it is attempting to connect to the network, and indicate whether it was successful by returning OK.
Set the MODEM to disable handshaking.
Type the following command, AT&K0, and press RETURN to disable handshaking.
Set the Baud Rate
Type the following to set the operational baud rate for the modem: AT&SB=2400 and press RETURN to change the baud rate immediately to 2400.
Access the Preferences menu, once more.
Press the F3 key to access the preferences menu.
Select the Baud submenu.
Press the B key to access the B)AUD submenu.
Select 2400 baud.
Press the 2 key to select 2400 baud.
Save your preferences.
Press the S key to save your preferences to disk.
Exit the preferences menu.
Press the E key to exit preferences, and return to the terminal.
Write the configuration to the MODEM
To ensure that the MODEM remembers these settings each time the computer is turned on, type AT&W and press RETURN to write the configuration to the non-volatile RAM of the MODEM.
The modem is now configured to connect to one of the PLATO services.

sect2.title: Configuring the WiMODEM (user port version)
sect2.para: The WiMODEM WIFI MODEM, by default is configured to respond at 300 baud. Thus, PLATOTerm must have its data rate, initially set to this speed, in order to do its initial configuration.

With each step of the procedure, either PLATOTerm will report OK, if the preference setting was successful, or the MODEM will report OK, when the MODEM command is successful. If you see ERROR, please try re-typing the command, and possibly checking your network configuration to ensure it is working correctly.

The following procedure will configure your MODEM to work with PLATOTerm64, as well as other terminal programs that can properly support user port modems: How to configure the WiMODEM
Access the Preferences menu.
Press F3 to access the Preferences menu.
Access the D)RIVER submenu.
Press D to select the D)RIVER submenu.
Select the UP2400 driver.
Press U to specify the UP2400 driver.
Select the Baud submenu.
Press B to select the B)AUD submenu.
Select 300 baud.
Press 3 to select 300 baud.
Exit preferences.
Press E to exit preferences, and return to the terminal.
Wake up the MODEM.
Once back in the terminal, type ATI and press RETURN. You will see the following output from the MODEM:WiModem – (C)2015-17 By Jim Drew Firmware:v2.00-12/24/17 Baud:300 Outgoing Port:1541 Incoming Port: 6400 SSID:No Router! MAC:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx IP:0.0.0.0 FCC ID: 2AHMR-ESP12F
Configure the WIFI Network
The WiModem provides three methods for selecting a Wifi Network, (a) Using your router's WPS button, (b) Interactively scanning the network and entering a passphrase, if needed, or ( c ) Manually specifying your network's SSID and Password, in a manner similar to the commodore4ever WIFI modem. Pick a particular method from this list, and follow the appropriate procedure:
Using your router's WPS feature.
Press your Router's WPS button.
Press the WPS button on your router. Follow your router's instructions on engaging the WPS feature.
Ask the MODEM to respond to WPS.
Type the command AT*WPS and press the RETURN key.
Ensure the modem connects to WPS.
The modem will respond with:WPS ACTIVATED
After a few moments, the MODEM will either respond with a successful connection to the WIFI network with the following message:Connected to: <your_ssid>
If the connection wasn't successful, you will instead see:No Router Located!
If this happens, please check your router configuration, or use one of the other methods to connect to your wireless network.
Interactively select the wireless network and enter password.
Ask the MODEM to scan for wireless networks.
Type the command AT*N and press RETURN. After a few moments, you'll see output similar to the following:Scanning available networks: Networks available: 2 0 – NETGEAR24 (-51 dBm), WPA2 1 – NETGEAR24-Guest (-52 dBm), Auto
Associate to the wireless network via its number.
Type the following to associate to a particular open network: AT*NSx, or
Type the following to associate to a particular secure network: AT*NSx,password
and press RETURN.
Be sure to replace x with the desired network number reported during the scan, and replace password with the appropriate password for the given network.
The MODEM should respond with:Looking for router...
Followed by:Connected to <network_name>
If there is a problem, the MODEM will respond with:No Router Located!
If this happens, please check your router configuration, or use one of the other methods to connect to your wireless network.
Manually associate with a wireless network
Ensure WIFI is working, by scanning for wireless networks
Type the command AT*N and press RETURN. After a few moments, you'll see output similar to the following:Scanning available networks: Networks available: 2 0 – NETGEAR24 (-51 dBm), WPA2 1 – NETGEAR24-Guest (-52 dBm), Auto
Set the desired wireless network name.
Type the following to associate to a particular open network: AT*SSID <your_ssid>, or
Type the following to associate to a particular secure network: AT*SSID <your_ssid>,password
and press RETURN.
Be sure to replace <your_ssid> with the desired network SSID, and replace password with the appropriate password for the given network.
The MODEM should respond with:Looking for router...
Followed by:Connected to <network_name>
If there is a problem, the MODEM will respond with:No Router Located!
If this happens, please check your router configuration, or use one of the other methods to connect to your wireless network.
Set the MODEM to disable handshaking.
Type the following command, AT&K0, and press RETURN to disable handshaking.
Set the Baud Rate
Type the following to set the operational baud rate for the modem: AT*B2400 and press RETURN to change the baud rate immediately to 2400.
Access the Preferences menu, once more.
Press the F3 key to access the preferences menu.
Select the Baud submenu.
Press the B key to access the B)AUD submenu.
Select 2400 baud.
Press the 2 key to select 2400 baud.
Save your preferences.
Press the S key to save your preferences to disk.
Exit the preferences menu.
Press the E key to exit preferences, and return to the terminal.
Write the configuration to the MODEM
To ensure that the MODEM remembers these settings each time the computer is turned on, type AT&W and press RETURN to write the configuration to the non-volatile RAM of the MODEM.
The modem is now configured to connect to one of the PLATO services.

sect2.title: Configuring the Jamming Signal WIFI Modem
sect2.para: The Commodore WIFI Modem from Jamming Signal works differently from the commodore4ever and WiModem devices, in that it also contains an OLED MicroView screen and hardware buttons on which the basic WIFI and modem configuration can be performed.

This modem is configured with the following default parameters:
2400 Baud
No handshaking
8 data bits
1 stop bit
No parity bit.
This means that this modem will work with PLATOTerm64 as it comes from the distribution disk, as all of the default preferences match exactly.

chapter.title: Using IRATA.ONLINE
chapter.para: Once your MODEM or Ethernet cartridge is configured, you can log onto IRATA.ONLINE.
If you haven't done so already, you need to have signed up for an account using the sign-up page and have received a reply email indicating that your account is now ready.

sect1.title: Using a Serial Device
sect1.para:
If you are using a serial device, you need to send a command to your MODEM, to "dial" IRATA.ONLINE. For all of the known internet MODEMs, the following command is sufficient:ATDTirata.online:8005. This tells the MODEM to connect to the hostname irata.online port number 8005. When connected, you will see the NOS banner from the IRATA.ONLINE system, shortly before switching into PLATO mode, similar to:Connecting to host - please wait ...
Connected
WELCOME TO THE NOS SOFTWARE SYSTEM. COPYRIGHT CONTROL DATA SYSTEMS INC. 1994. 90/06/27. 17.37.37. TE21 NOS CYBIS SYSTEM - CYBDEV. 1. NOS 2.8.7 871/871

sect1.title: Logging in
sect1.para: After a few moments, you will see the following output:
The system will ask you for your sign-on name:Enter your user name, and then press NEXT.
Enter the user name that you requested during sign-up, such as sam and press the RETURN key, as it is mapped to PLATO's NEXT key (see the keyboard chart)
The system will then ask you for your user group:Enter your user group, and then press NEXT.
Enter the user group that you requested during sign-up, such as commodor and press the RETURN key.

If this is the first time you've logged onto this account, the system will clear the screen, and ask you to provide a password:Choose a secret PASSWORD that you will remember. Do not tell anyone what it is.
As you type your password, several X's will appear so that nobody can see what you are typing.
Enter the password and press NEXT. >

If you have already logged on and provided a password, previously, the system will instead ask you for your password. It will also provide the following reminder:Remember to press SHIFT-STOP when you want to sign off.
Enter your password, then press NEXT to continue, or press LAB for additional options.
You will then be logged onto the system, and placed into the Main Menu.

sect1.title: The PLATO Keyboard
sect1.para: PLATO terminals feature a keyboard with many special keys, primarily to aid navigation, but also to access additional special characters that go beyond the standard American character set (such as greek letters and mathematical symbols.) The following chart demonstrates the keyboard mapping shows how the keys on the PLATO keyboard are mapped to keys on the Commodore keyboard. A larger version of this chart is in Appendix A.

figure.title: PLATO Keys on the Commodore Keyboard

sect1.para:
The normal keys are of course in the center, with the shifted keys appearing on top, for the numeric keys, just as in a traditional alphanumeric keyboard. The symbol keys have been shifted to match their Commodore equivalents, where possible, and special keys have been placed around the edges of each keycap in the chart:
The lower left symbols are accessed by pressing the COMMODORE key, along with the desired key.
The upper left symbols, by pressing the COMMODORE and SHIFT keys, along with the desired key.
The lower right symbols, by pressing the CTRL key, along with the desired key, and
The upper right symbols, by pressing the CTRL and SHIFT keys, along with the desired key.

Since Commodore keyboards have a STOP key, it is very handily mapped to PLATO's STOP key.
Each of the special PLATO keys, such as ANS, BACK, etc. are mapped mnemonically to the equivalent COMMODORE keycombination, and pressing SHIFT also engages the shifted key combinations for those special keys, such as SHIFT-BACK

sect1.title: The Main Menu
sect1.para: Once you log into the system, you will be presented with IRATA.ONLINE's menu system, which was designed as an easy way to navigate this PLATO system for new users. It is extremely consistent, and the keys and touch actions work consistently across its sub-menus.

caption.para: Going Clockwise from the top: The status display, Menu label, Menu Logo, Common Navigation Items, Navigation keys, and current menu items.

listitem.para: On the top left of the screen, is the status display. This will display the current date, time, and any system messages that need to be displayed for the user, such as whether the user has any personal notes available in his personal notesfile from other users.
The top right of the display, contains the menu label, such as MAIN MENU, or NOTES, in order to indicate where the user is within the menu system.
The lower right of the display contains a logo which changes depending on where the user is in the menu system. For the Main Menu, company logos are drawn here which are shown randomly.

The footer of the display contains a set of common menu items, which are visible from each and every menu, including:
Go - Type a lesson name to quickly jump to anywhere in the system.
Help - Help lessons to aid users.
Talk - Access the talk-o-matic multi-room chatting feature, to talk to other users.
Users - Show the currently logged on users.
Exit - Provide an opportunity to log off the system.

To the left of the logo, is the navigation legend. This shows the navigation keys that can be used on a particular page of the menu, to indicate whether a user can traverse sub-pages, or go back to a previous page.
Finally, the menu items themselves are visible, each menu item accessible with letters ranging from a to f. Pressing a letter, or touching an entry (e.g. with the mouse) will select the menu item.

sect2.title: Bulletins
sect2.para: The Bulletins screen shows system announcements that are meant for all system users. Once displayed, pressing any key, such as NEXT, will return the user back to the main menu.

sect2.title: Catalog
sect2.para: The CYBIS lesson catalog contains over 16,000 lessons, on a wide range of subjects. The catalog allows a user to traverse these lessons, and to try them.
